name: Herpes Simplex, Oral Lesions (Mouth, Lips)
general_information: Mucocutaneous Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infection, also known as oral labial HSV infection. It can manifest as gingivostomatitis or stomatitis, which is a vesicular infection of the mouth (usually anterior) and lips. The lesions are often referred to as fever blisters. They can be painful, more severe, and recurrent in immunocompromised hosts. Treatment is most effective when started during the prodromal phase (tingling/burning sensation) before lesions appear.
presenting_symptoms: Vesicular lesions on the mouth and lips, often preceded by symptoms of tingling or burning.
diagnostic_tests: Diagnosis is typically made based on clinical presentation.

oral_prodrome.dosage: 1500 mg one dose or 750 mg q12h x 1 day
oral_prodrome.notes: To be taken at the first sign of a prodrome.

topical.dosage: 1% cream q2h during day x 4 days

topical.notes: Approved for HIV patients only. Less preferred.

comments: A meta-analysis found Valacyclovir to be more effective overall for symptom reduction. Oral regimens are generally shorter course (Valacyclovir 1 day, Famciclovir 2 days) compared to topical regimens (Penciclovir 1 day, Acyclovir 0.5 day).
